sections.title: Course Introduction
sections.body: Welcome to the WBL (Web-Based Learning) module on Project Management Fundamentals, Tools, and Techniques! This module is designed to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of project management, project management functions, tools, techniques, and frameworks, and project lifecycle. sections.title: Defining “Project”
sections.list1: A project is a temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service or result.; A project is temporary in that it has a defined beginning and end in time, and therefore defined scope and resources.; A project is distinct from routine operations and has a singular goal.

sections.title: What is Project Management?
sections.body: The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet project requirements.
sections.body1: The practice of planning, organizing, and executing the tasks needed to turn a brilliant idea into a tangible product, service, or deliverable.
sections.body2: The discipline revolving around the execution of a project throughout its lifecycle.

sections.title: Project Management Tools, Techniques, and Frameworks
sections.subheader: What is the Project Management Method?
sections.body: The Project Management Method is a Consulting method that describes a process-based approach to plan, coordinate and control the execution of our services at the project level.
sections.body1: Traditional project management methodologies often follow a very linear and sequential approach. The scope and requirements are defined at the very beginning, and any changes to the defined scope must be reassessed and analyzed.
sections.body2: Agile methodologies, however, follows an iterative and “growing” approach. It welcomes frequently changing requirements and builds upon the collaboration and creativity of the team.

sections.title: Project Management Tools, Techniques, and Frameworks
sections.body: Agile is an umbrella term for various types of software development approaches.
sections.body1: Below are some of the most common practices used by agile practitioners:
sections.body2: SCRUM is a project management approach that anchors itself on teamwork, accountability and iterative progress toward a well-defined goal. Customers or stakeholders are actively involved in each sprint (fixed timeframes to deliver a feature).
sections.body3: KANBAN is a framework that requires real-time communication of capacity and full transparency of work. Work items are presented visually on what is called a “Kanban board.”
sections.body4: Lean Software Development (LSD) is an approach derived from the Lean Management. It is where the team produces a bare minimum version of a product, gathers feedback from users, and iterates it based on what they need and don’t need.

sections.title: Project Management Tools, Techniques, and Frameworks
sections.body: The hybrid approach is a combination of waterfall (traditional) and agile (adaptive) project management methodologies.

sections.title: Initiation Phase
sections.body: Projects can be initiated for various reasons, usually when there is a need for a change due to regulations, legislations, customer demands, strategy, cost pressures or combination of these.
sections.body1: There is a new banking regulation that requires us to perform a new set of processes.
sections.body2: Recent legislation changes require us to safeguard our customer data using certain protections.
sections.body3: Customers demand new innovative designs — we need to develop a new camera for mobile devices.
sections.body4: The company is expanding into a new region, we need to update our business strategy.
sections.body5: Our new products are costly. We need to reduce our costs to improve our profits.

sections.title: The Initiation Phase
sections.body: During Initiation Phase, we define a new project or a new phase of an existing project by obtaining authorization to start the project. Project’s scope and objectives are defined at this stage so that the benefits and outcomes of the project are achieved by the close of the project. One usual output of project initiation phase is a Project Charter.

sections.title: Project Charter
sections.body: Project Charter formally documents the overall objectives and scope of the project, as well as the general providing summary information on key aspects of the project.​
sections.body1: The process of creating the Project Charter serves to align stakeholder expectations and is used as foundation for preparing detailed plans all throughout the project lifecycle. When the project charter is approved, the project becomes officially authorized.
sections.list1: Key components of a project charter:; Project goals and objectives; Project background; Clearly defined project scope; Project governance; Key stakeholders; Project deliverable and key milestones; Summary of critical risks, assumptions and constraints; High level cost-estimate

sections.title: Framing a Project: Key Questions
sections.body: A complete understanding of what lies below the surface of a project is critical to a successful project initiation and eventually a successful project outcome.​
sections.body1: The following questions can be used to help you, and your team understand the ins and outs of a project:

sections.title: Project Charter on a page
sections.body: This Project Charter, 1-page summary example shows the major components.

sections.title: O-D-W Principle
sections.body: The O-D-W principle is a key approach for developing an emergent high-level plan, which is then revisited in subsequent phases for further development and refinement of a detailed / robust project plan. A thorough understanding and focus on O-D-W keeps the work of the project aligned with the overall business needs and outcomes.
sections.body1: During this early stage of project lifecycle, limited information may be available for answering detailed questions regarding the project. Establishing baseline understanding will help provide a measurement of the project’s progress and success.

sections.title: RACI Matrix
sections.body: The RACI Matrix is a simple charting tool used to define responsibility for each task within a project. It ensures that each task is assigned to the appropriate person or department to align responsibilities and set clear expectations.
sections.body1: RACI is an acronym with each letter representing a different role to perform.
sections.list1: The responsible employee physically does the work.; Who is assigned to work on this task?​​
sections.list2: The accountable employee oversees the work and is ultimately answerable for the activity or decision.; Who has the authority to sign off the work?​
sections.list3: The consulted employee offers advice or feedback to improve the work.​; Who can tell me more about this task?​
sections.list4: The informed party does not take part in the work but should be notified of the results.; Who must be kept updated about the progress?​​

sections.title: The Planning Phase
sections.body: Planning is an iterative process, and planning activities and outcomes mature and evolve as the project moves through the project lifecycle.

sections.title: What is a plan?
sections.list1: A formal, approved document used to guide both project execution and project control.; Used to document planning assumptions and decisions, facilitate communication among project stakeholders and document approved scope, cost and schedule baselines.; May be summarized or detailed.

sections.title: The Planning Phase
sections.body: The Plan phase takes available information and assembles it into a feasible project work plan to achieve client outcomes.
sections.body1: During this phase we establish the scope of the project, refine the objectives, and define the course of action required to attain the objectives that the project is undertaken to achieve.

sections.title: Building a Robust Project Plan
sections.body: A good, solid plan answers several questions related to the following aspects of a project:
sections.body1: What are the rationale, goals, and objectives of the project?
sections.body2: What is the scope, what are the deliverables and what are the outcomes?
sections.body3: How much time do we have to finish the tasks?
sections.body4: What are the methodology and approach we are going to follow? How much money do we have to spend?
sections.body5: What are the roles and responsibilities of people involved in the project?

sections.title: ODW: developing the workplan
sections.list1: What are the business objectives?; How will the project objectives serve the business objectives?
sections.body: Inputs from the Initiate phase
sections.list2: What work products and services, outputs and outcomes are required to satisfy all the project objectives?
sections.body1: Inputs from the Initiate phase
sections.list3: What workplan tasks are required to create all the project deliverables?
sections.body2: Output generated in the Planning phase

sections.title: Five steps crucial to planning
sections.list1: Identifying the specific activities that must be performed to produce the project deliverables identified in the work breakdown structure (WBS)
sections.list2: Arranging the activities to reflect their logical sequence and dependencies
sections.list3: Estimating effort and duration required to complete individual activities
sections.list4: Calculating a project schedule using the activities, their dependencies, resource assignments and estimated duration
sections.subheader4: Critical path identification (Critical Path Method or CPM)
sections.list5: The longest path of activities through the network that has no “float” or “slack,” i.e., any delay to the activities on this path delay the entire project; The critical path determines the duration of the project

sections.title: Six-steps — the ODW way
sections.list1: Review project objectives and input materials; Determine WBS approach; Create WBS hierarchy; Check WBS for coverage of project objectives
sections.list2: Define activities; Develop initial sequence of activities; Estimate amount of work
sections.list3: Assign project team roles and costs to tasks; Determine other types and costs of resources for each task (e.g., equipment, tools, facilities and expenses)
sections.list4: Identify a set of chronological milestones to serve as reference points; Identify target date and define milestone completion criteria
sections.list5: Select scheduling tool; Transform WBS into project activities; Define activity dependences and determine critical path; Assign resources and costs
sections.subheader5: Create a baseline and track the project plan
sections.list6: Baseline project plan for cost and schedule tracking; Begin tracking project weekly; Use Estimate to Complete (ETC) techniques

sections.title: Plan Development
sections.body: Each iteration of planning goes from a high-level strategic focus to a tactical, activity, and task focus.
sections.list1: Key notes to consider when developing a project plan:; A plan should have a target beginning and end, with each activity/task connected to one another; Different types of plan are created for different purposes; Level of details in the plan can be adjusted based on target audience

sections.body: Milestones are meaningful when communicating the status of a project with the project team, key stakeholders, and sponsors.
sections.body1: A milestone is reached, when at least one of the following is true:

sections.title: Six-steps to development
sections.body: There are six steps to develop a robust workplan using the ODW way:

sections.title: Work Breakdown Structure
sections.body: A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) is a listing of the discrete steps of work to be executed by a project team, described with an action orientation.
sections.body1: WBS helps clarify the tasks to be delivered on a project over a scheduled period of time.

sections.title: Estimating Work Effort
sections.list1: Estimate the work effort:; Follows WBS development approach of top-down or bottom-up; Technique used may vary based upon several factors, including size, scope and complexity of the project
sections.list2: Important Points:; Estimating is an integral part of Project Management.; The objective is to generate quantifiable estimates, along with associated assumptions and risks, which represent the effort and cost for a set of activities needed to produce deliverables.; Accurate estimates are critical to the success of a project. The best source of an estimate is to look at history. Remember, accuracy in estimating means being close not exact.; Good estimates do not guarantee a successful project, however bad estimates virtually guarantee failure.

sections.title: Estimating Work Effort
sections.list1: Important Points:; Provide a quantitative assessment of the number of work periods to complete an activity; Provide range of uncertainty when estimating an activity (2 weeks +/- 2 days); Document assumptions made to derive the estimates; Update the activity list with any further breakdowns as a result of the duration estimates
sections.list2: Additional Important Points:; Project scope and clear work breakdown structure are defined; Base quantities of deliverables and activities are identified and documented; Auditable and repeatable estimating process; Underlying project assumptions are well defined and documented; Uncertainties are understood, documented and incorporated; It passes the “reasonability” test for feasibility/sensibility; Agreement/buy-in from the team

sections.title: Estimate the Resources and Costs
sections.list1: Estimating resources and cost — experience, practice and guidance
sections.list2: Project Managers seek guidance on estimating method to be used from the practice leaders

sections.title: Assigning Resources and Delegation
sections.body: Assignment is the matchmaking of a resource to a task in a project plan
sections.subheader: Assigning resources allows you to answer
sections.list1: Who should be working on what task and when?;Have you assigned so many tasks that a resource is beyond capacity?; Are you expecting a resource to work on a task when they are not available?; Assigning a resource to a task enables you to track the progress of the resource’s work on the task.
sections.body1: Delegation is deciding the right person accompanied with responsibility and accountability to deliver a work effort
sections.subheader1: Revisit your project plan when delegating tasks
sections.list2: What is the activity all about?; What needs to be delivered?; When do you expect to start and complete?; Are there any dependencies to consider?; Who are your workstream members?; Delegating effectively empowers your team to gain control, hone their skills, and develop sense of autonomy.

sections.title: Milestones defined
sections.list1: A milestone marks a point in time for which one or more of the following is true:; Marks the completion of a group of related activities or deliverables; Is where key decisions or key deliverables must be completed for the project to advance; Is generally on a critical path for the project’s completion; Can be tied to another project such that achievement of one of your project’s milestones may impact progress on other projects; Is agreed upon with the project team, key stakeholders and sponsors; Is meaningful when communicating the status of a project with the project team, key stakeholders and sponsors; Milestones establish a commitment between the project sponsor and project team
sections.list2: Benefits of using Milestones:; Ease and simplify communication across the Project Sponsor, Project Team, and PMO; Create high-level visibility: Create high-level accountability; Ensure facilitated agreement at all levels; Ensure clear understanding of the milestone’s intent; Support metrics
sections.list3: Defining Milestones; Milestones are most effective when all parties with a stake in the project are involved in their selection.; Review project objectives and schedule; Draft milestones with project team; Review and update milestones with project sponsor; Receive approval from project sponsor; Track and monitor milestones against project plan

sections.title: Critical Path Method
sections.body: Critical Path Method or CPM is used to build, calculate, and evaluate the plan’s activities and timing. The CPM is used to evaluate and optimize project plans.
sections.body1: Critical Path is a series of tasks that will extend the project’s end date, if those tasks are delayed. These tasks have a single, pre-determined time estimate. It can also be explained as the longest-duration path through a network diagram and determines the shortest time to complete the project.
sections.body2: It is worth noting that there may be tasks with a Float/Stack value which allows for a task to be delayed from its expected start date, but without impact to the project’s finish date.

sections.title: Baseline and track the project plan
sections.list1: Baseline a project to track the iterative changes and impacts to time, scope and cost; Baselines are a snapshot of the project attributes at a certain time; Project Management tools and applications can compare later changes to initial baseline conditions;  Differences between the baseline and later versions can help Project Managers adjust or recover the plan; Baseline tracking contributes to continuous improvement of project planning in the specific environment

sections.title: The Project Plan is ready for a baseline when:
sections.list1: The Project Manager has received all estimate and schedule inputs from team and has drafted the Project Plan and Schedule.; The Project Manager has met with the team, reviewed the plan and obtained buy-in for the plan.; The Project Manager has met and discussed the team’s proposed plan with executive leadership and receives approval or “sign off”.; The Project Manager has met with the PMO to review and obtain sign off on the plan.; All team, leadership and client changes are included in the plan.

sections.title: Creating a Project Plan
sections.body: A Project Plan is a documented plan critical to tracking progress and reporting status. It describes how the project will be executed, monitored, and controlled.
sections.body1: This plan is a summary level document containing the results of planning. It serves as a complement to the Project Charter and represents a more detailed view of specific work streams and activities conducted during the project.
sections.list1: Columns Defined:; Workstream - The name of the group for which specific developed and assigned.; Activity - A brief note about work to be performed.; Dependency - A relationship in which a task is connected or reliant on another task for execution or completion.; Deliverable/Milestone - The finished work product resulting from a process (deliverable); or a significant point, occurrence or outcome in the project (milestone).; Status – Following the RAG principle for the 3 main status

sections.title: Creating a Project Plan
sections.body: Individual supporting plans or work products are created to supplement the overall Project Plan baseline. Each supporting plan is created to document baseline data and/or changes and updates for reference.
sections.list1: Communications Management Plan - component of the project management plan that describes how project communications will be planned, structured, monitored, and controlled; Stakeholder Engagement Plan - component of the project management plan and identifies the management strategies required to effectively engage stakeholders. The stakeholder management plan can be formal or informal, highly detailed or broadly framed, based on the needs of the project; Scope Management Plan - describes how the project scope will be planned, structured, and controlled; Change Control Plan - sets expectations on how the approach to changes will be managed, what defines a change, the purpose and role of the change control board, and the overall change management process; Risk Management Plan - component of the project management plan and describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed; Schedule Management Plan - establishes the criteria and the activities for developing, monitoring, and controlling the schedule

sections.title: The Execution Phase
sections.body: The Execute, and the Monitor and Control phases focus on task delivery and project oversight. These two phases are nearly always simultaneous, but each has a distinct purpose and objective. Monitor and Control provides oversight of the Plan, the Execute and the Close phases.
sections.body1: The Execute phase consists of those processes that are performed to complete the work defined in the Project Management plan to satisfy the project specifications. This process involves coordinating with people and resources, managing stakeholder expectations, as well as integrating and performing the activities of the project in accordance with the Project Management plan.
sections.body2: The Monitor and Control phase consists of those processes required to track, review and orchestrate the progress and performance of the project; identify any areas in which changes to the plan are required and initiate the corresponding changes.

sections.title: Leading the work
sections.body: “Successful Project Managers are managers who practice both strong management skills and effective leadership skills.” Reference: Kumar, Victoria (2009). PMI Global Congress 2009.
sections.body1: This assertion is especially important during the execution of the project work
sections.list1: Project Managers must lead the team by:; Motivating and Inspiring - Project leaders will constantly be encouraging and prompting their people to do the best work possible and acknowledge those that produce both in public and private.; Team Building - Project leaders are deliberately looking for opportunities to help team members work with each other to achieve their collective goals. On larger projects, project leadership fosters the process and mechanisms to enable sub-team leads to do the same.; Negotiating and communicating - Project leaders' model desired and exemplary communication skills. This includes creating a healthy environment where open and honest communications carry throughout the team and stakeholders.; Listening and influencing - Project leaders must listen to their team members’ ideas and concerns — and then acknowledge and show consideration for their contribution to the discussion. This happens before the leader issues an opinion or decision.

sections.title: Project execution
sections.body: Since changes will happen during project execution. Project Managers must manage the delivery of the work while leading the team and stakeholders through changes to the project triangle.

sections.title: Key Differences Between Waterfall and Agile Project Management
sections.body: PMOs that are experimenting with Agile often find that a Hybrid approach can be most effective to accelerate traditional Waterfall projects while Agile principles are becoming fully understood and implemented.

sections.title: Role of the PMO
sections.body: The Project Management Office (PMO) is the control room for managing project control processes for large projects or programs.

sections.title: Monitoring and Control Phase

sections.body: Aim of the Phase: Provide critical visibility and insight to project against plan and initiate corrective action as needed.

sections.list3: Control changes and recommend actions (preventive or corrective); Monitor ongoing activities and gauge against project performance measures.; Maintain project change control processes.

sections.title: Monitoring and controlling projects when events change plans
sections.body: When the plan gets challenged, you need to return to the key project questions drilled out from the Initiate and Plan and captured in the associated artifacts.

sections.title: Stakeholder management: who are the stakeholders?
sections.body: Stakeholders are a range of people who have a vested interest in the project’s progress and success.
sections.list1: Benefit or are impacted directly or indirectly from the change or project outcomes; Behavior’s may need to change; Influence the people involved in the project; Control resources and commodities needed to carry out the project tasks and activities; Heavily influence others who are affected by the project’s outcomes

sections.title: Stakeholder management: who are the stakeholders?
sections.body: Stakeholders are a range of people who have a vested interest in the project’s progress and success.
sections.list1: Sponsor - Owns the project, accountable for its delivery.; Project Manager - Responsible for successful delivery.; Functional Leads - Making investments in time/money.; Key Stakeholders - Clients, beneficiaries and/or impacted parties.; Project Team -Job satisfaction and reputations depend on it.; Other PMs - May share dependencies and resources.

sections.title: Importance of effective Stakeholder Management
sections.body: When effectively employed, stakeholder management is critical to a project’s success.
sections.list1: Achievement of strategic objectives through positive relationships with stakeholders; Proactive management of expectations through a defined process; Consistent communications use and information dissemination using a common language; Effective Change Management activities using a formalized process and discipline

sections.title: Stakeholder management and the Project Manager
sections.body: Apply a structured approach to understanding what information each stakeholder needs and how best to communicate it to them.
sections.list1: Identify all key people or groups impacted by the project; Analyze their interest, influence and impact on the project
sections.list2: Determine the stakeholder information needs and define and plan communications approach
sections.list3: Make relevant information available to project stakeholders as planned, using methods/media that are fit-for-purpose
sections.list4: Communicate and work with stakeholders to meet their priority needs and address issues/concerns as they occur
sections.list5: Collect and communicate performance information, including status reports, progress measurement and forecasts

sections.title: Stakeholder Management
sections.body: It is important to communicate and work well with your stakeholders’ needs and expectations and address issues as they occur. When effectively employed, stakeholder management is critical to a project’s success.
sections.body1: Know WHO your stakeholders are
sections.list1: Stakeholders both internal and external can help achieve project objectives; What to do: Aim to create a positive relationship with them
sections.body2: Know WHEN and WHERE to discuss project issues and concerns with  your stakeholders
sections.list2: Keeping stakeholders engaged and informed can reduce uncertainties and promote supportive relationship; What to do: Establish checkpoints or cadences with different level of stakeholders (e.g. weekly or monthly cadences)
sections.body3: Know HOW to communicate your items
sections.list3: Leveling out understanding among stakeholders can help establish better appreciation of items being raised; What to do: Use a common language and standardized terminology when reporting

sections.title: Determining the stakeholders’ role
sections.body: The RACI Matrix is a simple charting tool used to define responsibility for each task within a project. It ensures that each task is assigned to the appropriate person or department to align responsibilities and set clear expectations.
sections.body1: RACI is an acronym with each letter representing a different role to perform.
sections.list1: The responsible employee physically does the work.; Who is assigned to work on this task?​​
sections.list2: The accountable employee oversees the work and is ultimately answerable for the activity or decision.; Who has the authority to sign off the work?​
sections.list3: The consulted employee offers advice or feedback to improve the work.​; Who can tell me more about this task?​
sections.list4: The informed party does not take part in the work but should be notified of the results.; Who must be kept updated about the progress?​​

sections.title: The project manager and governance
sections.body: Planning effective governance structure and practices sets up the project for success.

sections.title: Risks, Assumptions, Issues, and Dependencies
sections.body: The RAID matrix allows the project team to document, proactively account for, and address items interrelated with the project.
sections.body1: The staff on a project is often responsible for identifying the risks and helping to complete the RAID tool.
sections.list1: Risks; A risk is defined as a future threat to the overall success of a project or a contingent part; Every risk has an associated likelihood, and therefore, severity rating; Risks must be mitigated or accepted
sections.list2: Assumptions; An assumption is a statement accepted as fact; Assumptions must be validated
sections.list3: Issues; An issue is an immediate formally defined concern that requires action; It impedes the progress of a Workstream or the Program and about which no agreement to resolve has been reached
sections.list4: Dependencies; Dependencies are relationships between products or tasks; For example, one product may be made up of several other “dependent” products or a task may not begin until a “dependent” task is complete

sections.title: RAID Summary
sections.body: Unlike risks and issues, assumptions and dependencies in the RAID log are documented instances where the project has determined that there is an assumption or dependency which exists, so that in the process of resolving issues or mitigating risks, these factors are not missed — and can be incorporated into the solution.

sections.title: Your Response to Risks identified
sections.body: As we assess the risk, we should also consider balancing cost, time, and scope of the project.
sections.list1: ACCEPT - It might not always be cost-effective to avoid, transfer, or mitigate all risks, at some point a certain level of risk must be accepted.; AVOID - Risk avoidance is the simplest response strategy – basically this involves just not going forward with the activity that posed the risk.; TRANSFER - Risk transfer strategies seek to pass the risk off to a third party.; MITIGATE - Risk mitigation involves trying to reduce an existing risk.

sections.title: Issue Management
sections.body: The issue lifecycle is straightforward. The process helps the project team to understand what to do with issues once identified. The Project Manager should ensure that the project team has the required skills to facilitate the movement of an issue throughout the process.
sections.list1: Project Managers should be able to answer the following questions regarding issue control:; Who will be assigned for resolving the issue?; How will the team know when to escalate an issue to management or the steering committee? Consider creating a matrix of potential business impact versus issue complexity to help decide which issues should be taken to higher levels of management.; Which criteria will determine an issue's priority status?; Who will set the target resolution date?; How will issues be communicated within the team?

sections.title: Project Status Report
sections.body: Status Report is a summary of an ongoing project performance information for a specific period of time. It is regularly updated and presented to key stakeholders and sponsor all throughout the execution of a project.
sections.list1: Follow the RAG Status Guidance and use the color indicators below to determine the status of a Milestone or Budget (Planned vs Actual):; COMPLETED - Fully achieved; DELAYED - Project not on track, has significant challenges and/or issues that can impact overall success of an expected outcome; AT RISK - Project on track, has significant challenges and/or issues that can impact overall success of an expected outcome; ON TRACK - Project on track, no significant challenges and/or issues that can impact overall success of an expected outcome

sections.title: Project Status Report
sections.body: Timeline, Cost, and Scope changes typically happen during Execution. A Project Manager must be prepared to manage the delivery of the work while leading the team through the process of adjusting the work plan and resetting expectations as the work develops.
sections.body1: A Project Manager should also continuously refresh and affirm many of the tasks, inputs and outputs in all of the phases from Initiate through Monitor and Control.
sections.body2: Some of the foundational documents will need updating throughout the project, and sometimes a formal Change Request is needed.

sections.title: Knowledge Check 12
sections.body: What is the significance of a status report?

q_selection.A: The process helps the project team to understand what to do with issues once identified.
q_selection.B: A summary of an ongoing project performance information for a specific period of time.
q_selection.C: Risk transfer strategies seek to pass the risk off to a third party
q_selection.D: Events that will have an adverse impact on your project if they occur.

sections.title: Project Monitoring & Control Phase: Summary
sections.body: Track, review, and regulate the progress and performance of the project; identify any areas in which changes to the plan are required; and initiate the corresponding changes
sections.list1: Identifying Risks, Assumptions, Issues, and Dependencies; Recommending and controlling changes that are corrective and preventive in nature
sections.list2: Risk Register; Status Report

sections.title: Closing Phase
sections.body: Closing the project consists of those processes performed to conclude all activities and formally complete the project, phase, or contractual obligations.
sections.dody1: This activity, when completed, verifies that the defined processes are completed within to close the project or a project phase, as appropriate, and formally establishes that the project or project phase is complete.​

sections.title: Closing Phase
sections.list1: IMPORTANT OUTPUT:; Accepted deliverables; Supplier contract close document; Corrective actions; Team performance assessments; Documented lessons learned; Team resources released; Project close report

sections.title: Project team debrief and lessons learned
sections.body: Ways through which Project Managers facilitate the gathering and documentation of intellectual property
sections.list1: Conducting the final project team debrief meeting; Conducting a project close meeting with sponsor; Documenting and validating project outcomes against the project objectives
sections.list2: Elements of a good project team debrief include:;Input from all teams (including client members, if appropriate); Clear expectations of transparency; Discussion addresses mobilization, communications, planning, quality, resourcing and teaming; Team members are prepared to share observations of lessons learned
sections.list3: Capturing lessons learned:;What worked well and why?; What did not work well and why?; How could the team do better next time?

sections.title: Project Close Report
sections.body: Summarizes the overall performance of a project against objectives, deliverables, and milestones. Includes a simplified view of any remaining outstanding issues and variance analysis in project scope, time, and cost.
sections.list1: Executive Summary – Provides a brief overview of the project, its objectives, and high-level outcomes; Project Objectives – Be specific about any deviations from the original objectives.; Scope – highlight any scope creep or changes in the project; Deliverables – we can group them into milestones and highlight specific challenges; Successes – discuss any notable milestones and accomplishments; Challenges – discuss here how these challenges were addressed; Lessons learned – Explain and discuss how these lessons can be applied to future projects; Risk Management – also mention if they materialized or not; Quality and performance – you may explain here the project’s quality control process; Recommendations – this is an opportunity to discuss future pursuits or projects
sections.body1: The Project Manager presents the final report to the client project sponsor and other key stakeholders and must obtain an approval to close the project.
sections.body2: If there are outstanding issues preventing the sponsor from approving the close, the Project Manager and sponsor should create an action plan with a planned completion date.

sections.title: Learning Summary
sections.list1: Now that you have completed this lesson, you should be able to: What is project lifecycle; Different phases of project lifecycle and its components; Manage end-to-end project cycle from initiation to closing, as well as in performing the execution of the project and continuous monitoring and control of the project.
